title: Perma-tanned and partying with stars, Robert Evans was the last of Hollywood's golden boys
text:
There’s a certain image of the Hollywood producer as a player – to quote Robert Altman’s 1992 insider satire – which just passed away with Robert Evans. If a vision comes to you of a perma-tanned party animal, in tinted shades and bathrobe, conducting business meetings around his own swimming pool, it could be that you’ve seen Wag the Dog, Barry Levinson’s 1997 comedy about the Hollywoodisation of politics, in which Dustin Hoffman’s character, Stanley Motss, is meant to be a mischievous portrait of his old friend. Hoffman never admitted that Evans was his source of inspiration, but everyone in the industry – including Evans himself – surely knew.
